description: From French lamenter, from Latin lāmentor (“I wail, weep”), from lāmenta (“wailings, laments, moanings”); with formative -mentum, from the root *la-, probably ultimately imitative. Also see latrare.

entries.meaning: An expression of grief, suffering, sadness or regret.

verbs.description: lament (third-person singular simple present laments, present participle lamenting, simple past and past participle lamented)

entries.meaning: (intransitive) To express grief; to weep or wail; to mourn.
examples: Ye shall weep and lament, but the world shall rejoice.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To feel great sorrow or regret; to bewail.
examples: By the end, Sunderland were lucky to lose by the same scoreline Northampton Town suffered against Southampton, in 1921. The Sunderland manager, Gus Poyet, lamented that it was “the most embarrassed I’ve ever been on a football pitch, without a doubt”.
